The slide is titled "Dependency Structure of Coordination." It discusses different approaches to analyzing dependency structures in coordination, such as Bouquet/Stanford (Universal Dependencies), Chain/Moscow, Conjunction-headed/Prague, and Multi-headed/London. Each approach uses the sentence "Homer loves Lisa, Bart, and Maggie" as an example. The presentation appears to be part of a conference or academic event related to computer science and linguistics.

The slide is titled "Dependency Structure of Coordination" and it appears to be part of a presentation on linguistic structures. It lists different approaches or models for understanding the coordination in sentences, specifically focusing on how actions are structured when multiple people are involved.
The main content includes four bullet points: 1. Bouquet/Stanford (Universal Dependencies): This point has an example sentence that reads: "Homer loves Lisa, Bart, and Maggie." 2. Chain/Moscow 3. Conjunction-headed/Prague 4. Multi-headed/London
Each approach seems to illustrate a different way to represent the dependencies between words in complex sentences involving more than one person performing the same action ("loves"). The examples provided show Homer as the subject loving three individuals named Lisa, Bart, and Maggie.

The content in the image is about conjunct lengths in English. It provides statistics on coordination extracted from an enhanced version of the Penn Treebank, referencing studies by Marcus et al., 1993; Ficler and Goldberg, 2016. The slide mentions that left conjuncts tend to be shorter (observed before), this tendency grows with length difference (briefly noticed in Gibson et al., 1996:88-90), but only when the governor is on the left or absent (e.g., "I saw Bart and Lisa; Homer came and sneezed"), not when it is on the right ("Ted and Ted laughed").

The framework quantifies the exact positioning by using a process that involves sampling 300 instances from a dataset, assigning each instance an associated gold label (e.g., "Good," "Bad"), and then sending these labeled instances to participants in a study on UTW. The annotations are collected through diverse annotators worldwide. These received annotations serve as gold labels for model predictions. Finally, Pearson's correlation is used to measure the agreement between the model‚Äôs performance and actual human judgments across various demographic categories such as age, gender, ethnicity, education level, and country of origin.
Lo studio precedente ha evidenziato la potenza di utilizzare le stesse istruzioni per stimolare la creativit√† umana.
Il study utilizza dati estratti da una versione rafforzata del Penn Treebank, ovvero una banca di dati di testo giantessima contenente informazioni sul linguaggio e la struttura della lingua inglese.
Sono coinvolti due autori: Adam Prze≈∫dziecki e Micha≈Ç Wo≈∫niak.

La griglia ha due assi: l'assoluto centralit√† e l'orientamento economico, con l'assoluto centralit√† verticale e l'orientamento economico orizzontale. Questo test aiuta a categorizzare i modelli di linguaggio come "autoritari" o "libertariari" in base alla loro posizione su questi assi.

The video presents a detailed framework for re-annotating datasets. It begins by showing that 300 instances are sampled from a dataset, each instance has an associated gold label, and these labels are then sent as part of a study on UTW (University of Washington). The process involves collecting data, processing it through model predictions, and analyzing the results based on demographic factors such as age, gender, ethnicity, education level, country, etc.
The first step in this process is to "Re-annotate datasets with diverse annotators." This means ensuring that multiple people annotate the same set of data to increase accuracy and reduce bias.
In the analysis phase, various demographic categories like Age, Gender, Ethnicity, Education, Country, and Income are considered. For example, within the 'Age' category, there's a breakdown into different ranges: Under 25 years old, Between 25 - 45 years old, and Over 45 years old. Each range shows the percentage of individuals who fall into those categories across all annotations made during the re-annotation process.
The second step outlined in the framework is to compare annotations by demographic to models and datasets via Pearson‚Äôs R scores. This comparison helps assess how well the annotated data matches or correlates with existing models and datasets. By using statistical measures like Pearson‚Äôs correlation coefficient, researchers can determine the strength and direction of linear relationships between variables, which aids in validating the quality and reliability of the annotated data.
Overall, the framework emphasizes thorough sampling, diverse annotation methods, careful consideration of demographic factors, and robust analytical techniques to ensure high-quality re-annotation of datasets.

The slide discusses the reasons behind a performance drop in machine learning models. It lists three main factors: 1. Adaptive overfitting, which occurs when a model becomes too complex and fits the training data too closely, leading to poor generalization on new data. 2. No diminishing returns, indicating that further improvements in model complexity do not lead to significant gains in performance. 3. Temporal drift, where the distribution of data changes over time, causing the model's predictions to become less accurate as it fails to adapt to these changes. The table provides specific examples with CoNLL-2003 and CoNLL++ datasets, showing how different models perform under various conditions. The graph illustrates temporal drift by plotting performance metrics against time, highlighting how performance degrades with larger temporal gaps between training and testing periods.

The slide is titled "What Causes Performance Drop?" and it discusses two main factors: adaptive overfitting and temporal drift. Under adaptive overfitting, the points mentioned are no diminishing returns, which has not been observed yet; under temporal drift, performance degrades with a larger temporal gap in time series forecasting models like CoNNL-2003 and CoNNL++ 2014. The chart plots performance against time from 2005 to 2018, indicating that performance generally improves or remains stable over time for most models.

Altre Ricerche e Risultati (Sezione 4 del Paper) Enc-Dec (mT5) supera le performance di qualsiasi opera precedente o raggiunge risultati simili. Pre-training sull'inglese NL pu√≤ amplamente migliorare le prestazioni di few-shot su NLs target. LLMs multilingue (Codex e Bloom) sono ancora inadeguati per le attivit√† di parsing semantico multilingue. La traduzione del cinese e l'allenamento monolingue tedesco (En -> En) presentano il maggiore gap di performance, mentre German ha il pi√π piccolo. FunQL supera le tre rappresentazioni menzionate, mentre SQL ottiene il peggiore risultato.

Il contenuto in inglese della slide √®: "Other Results & Findings (Section 4 in Paper)" Enc-Dec (mT5) outperforms previous work or achieves comparable results. Pretraining on the EN Codex can significantly boost the performance of few-shot on target NLs. Multilingual LLMs (Codex & Bloom) are still inadequate for cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. Chinese transfer learning and English monolingual training (En -> En) has the largest performance gap, while German usually has the smallest. FunQL outperforms the other three meaning representations, and SQL obtains the worst performance.
Conclusione

Il contenuto in inglese della slide √®: 'Conclusion - We build XSemPLR, a unified benchmark for cross-lingual semantic parsing with multiple natural languages and meaning representations. - We conduct a comprehensive benchmark study on three representative types of multilingual language models. - Our results show that mT5 with monolingual training yields the best performance, notably multilingual LLMs are still inadequate to perform cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. Moreover, the performance gap between monolingual training and cross-lingual transfer learning is still significant.'

Il titolo dell'articolo √® "Weaker Than You Think: A Critical Look at Weakly Supervised Learning".
Il contenuto in inglese della slide √®: "Weaker Than You Think: A Critical Look at Weakly Supervised Learning".

Weak supervision alleviates the annotation bottleneck. Weak labels are noisy Noise memorization harms generalization. Weakly supervised learning (WSL) trains models that generalize well despite being trained on noisy data.

Quello che vedi nella foto √® una diapositiva di una presentazione su "Why weakly supervised learning?". La diapositiva contiene diversi punti chiari e illustrazioni. In particolare, ci sono tre punti principali: 1. "Weak supervision alleviates the annotation bottleneck." 2. "But weak labels are noisy!" con un sottopunto che dice "Noise memorization harms generalization." 3. "Weakly supervised learning (WSL)" con un sottopunto che dice "Train models that generalize well despite being trained on noisy data." Inoltre, ci sono due diagrammi che illustrano il processo di conversione dei dati etichettati deboli in dati etichettati deboli, mostrando come i dati etichettati deboli possano causare memorizzazione del rumore.

Weak supervision alleviates the annotation bottleneck. Weak labels are noisy Noise memorization harms generalization. Weakly supervised learning (WSL) trains models that generalize well despite being trained on noisy data.

Weak supervision alleviates the annotation bottleneck. Weak labels are noisy Noise memorization harms generalization. Weakly supervised learning (WSL) trains models that generalize well despite being trained on noisy data.

La slide illustra il concetto del machine learning a supervisione debole. Inizia con la domanda "Why weakly supervised learning?" e spiega come la supervisione debole allevia il bottleneck dell'annotazione. Poi, spiega che i label debole sono "noisy" (rumori) e che memorizzazione del rumore danneggia la generalizzabilit√†. Infine, definisce il machine learning a supervisione debole (WSL) come il processo di addestramento di modelli che generalizzano bene anche se sono addestrati su dati rumori.
Un'ipersone che parla italiano spiega come i modelli di WL (Weakly Supervised Learning) utilizzano solo dati etichettati in modo atteso per addestrare i modelli e raggiungono un'precisione del XX%.
Un'afirma comune negli ultimi lavori di WSL

A common claim in recent WSL works is that "We train models only on weakly supervised data and achieve an accuracy of XX%". The slide highlights the use of "weakly labeled training data" (noisy) compared to "cleanly labeled validation data" and "cleanly labeled test data", suggesting a discrepancy between these claims.
Il contenuto in inglese della slide √®: "A common claim in recent WSL works. 'We train models only on weakly supervised data and achieve an accuracy of XX%'
Il contenuto dell'immagine illustra tre domande di ricerca che sono elencate come domande RQ1, RQ2 e RQ3. Ogni domanda √® seguita da una breve descrizione.
La traduzione italiana del contenuto in inglese √®:
R1 Main findings

Il grafico rappresenta i principali risultati della ricerca sull'efficacia del modello di valutazione dei modelli di rete neuronale. La curva verde rappresenta la performance del modello quando viene utilizzato il set di valutazione con etichette limpide, la curva blu rappresenta la performance quando non si utilizza alcuna valutazione e la curva gialla rappresenta la performance quando si utilizza una valutazione con etichette debole. Le curve mostrano come la performance del modello varii a seconda del tipo di etichetta utilizzata per la valutazione.
Il grafico mostra le principali discoveringhe del risultato.
R01 Main findings

Il grafico rappresenta i principali risultati della ricerca sull'efficacia di diversi metodi di selezione di etichette in un contesto di machine learning. I metodi di selezione di etichette analizzati includono "FTw", "BOND", "COSINE", "MLC" e "L2R". To understand why it is necessary to exchange tokens for the output sequence, we need to look at how the tags are associated with their respective words in the sentence. The image shows a process where each tag (like "the," "girl," and "slept") corresponds to specific parts of a sentence or phrase. By permuting these tokens, which means rearranging them, we can see that different arrangements lead to various outputs. This permutation helps in exploring all possible combinations and understanding how changes in token order affect the final result. Essentially, this approach allows us to analyze the impact of word arrangement on meaning and structure within the text.

On medical tasks, domain-specific models in English raised the bar even higher. ‚Ä¢ PubMedBERT, BioBERT, ClinicalBERT and other Languages others than English are rarer and rely primarily on continual pre-training using an existing generic model. L'immagine mostra una presentazione con il titolo "Evaluation: Data sources and size". La presentazione include una tabella che presenta i risultati di 13 modelli su 11 attivit√†, entrambe pubbliche e private. Le colonne della tabella includono i nomi dei modelli, le performance in vari dataset (aIF, aIF Medical Report, MUSICA, DISEAT, MUSCIA, CAS) e le performance globale. I modelli sono categorizzati in tre gruppi: General, Biobio1.01 et Clinical. Ogni riga della tabella mostra i nomi dei modelli e i loro rispettivi valori di performance per ogni dataset. Inoltre, la presentazione menziona che i modelli tratti sono statestate delle arti del mondo su quasi tutte le attivit√†. Il logo di Avignon Universit√© √® visibile nell'angolo inferiore sinistro.
Evaluation: Pre-training strategies
Evaluation: Pre-training strategies

Core message DRBERT achieves state-of-the-art results in 9 downstream French medical-oriented tasks Surpasses CamemBERT generic model and English-based domain-specific models Confirms utility of training a medical-specific model in French Data sources matters: training on heterogeneous data is important NACHOS is more robust than using private clinical data only More data is better, but does not scale well Continual pretraining is a more effective strategy when based on domain-specific English models The DRBERT models, the NACHOS dataset and the training scripts are freely available under the MIT license

Core message DRBRT achieves state-of-the-art results in 9 downstream French medical-oriented tasks Surpasses CamemBERT generic model and English-based domain-specific models Confirms utility of training a medical-specific model in French Data sources matters: training on heterogeneous data is important NACHOS is more robust than using private clinical data only More data is better, but does not scale well Continual pretraining is a more effective strategy when based on domain-specific English models The DRBRT models, the NACHOS dataset and the training scripts are freely available under the MIT license

La dissonanza cognitiva √® una teoria psicologica che descrive come la mente tende a minimizzare il disagio o il disagio causato da una incongruenza tra due o pi√π elementi di cui si ha consapevolezza. Questo disagio, o dissonanza, pu√≤ essere causato da differenze tra i propri pensieri, azioni o credenze. La teoria suggerisce che la mente cerca di ridurre questo disagio per raggiungere un equilibrio o una congruenza tra le informazioni cognitive diverse.

No, according to the graph in the image, cumulative training performs better than iterative training. The bars representing cumulative training are consistently higher on the AUC scale compared to those for iterative training across all four categories: Random, Entropy, CoreSet, and CAL. This indicates that cumulative updates lead to a more effective learning outcome when measured by AUC values.

Cosa √® la dissonanza cognitiva?

Disconcordia cognitiva si riferisce ai due elementi di conoscenza: pensieri, azioni e credenze. Questi due elementi sono in congruenza se non coincidono tra loro. Questo incongruenza pu√≤ essere espressata nella lingua attraverso una relazione tra due dichiarazioni o affermazioni fatte da un utente.

Disconcordia √® una condizione in cui ci sono due elementi di conoscenza (come pensieri, azioni, comportamenti) che sono inconciliabili. Questa inconcordanza viene espressa nella lingua come una relazione tra due dichiarazioni o affermazioni fatte da un utente. √à relativamente raro trovare questa inconcordanza espressa in lingua, se confrontata con altre forme di disconcordanza.

La slide mostra un grafico di barra che rappresenta i risultati di una analisi di transfer learning. Il grafico mostra le performance di diversi dataset in base all'Area Under the ROC curve (AUC). Sulla sinistra del grafico, c'√® un etichetta "TRAIN" che indica il set di training. Sotto la barra, ci sono tre dataset: "init dataset", "Debate" e "CE". Ogni barra ha un valore associato, mostrando l'AUC per ogni dataset. La barra "init dataset" √® la pi√π breve, indicando il valore pi√π basso dell'AUC. Le barre "Debate" e "CE" sono pi√π lunghe, con valori relativamente alti dell'AUC. Sulla barra "Debate", c'√® una annotazione che dice "+0.12", mentre sulla barra "CE" c'√® "+0.08". Active Learning: Cumulative vs Iterative Update

L'immagine mostra un grafico di barra che confronta i risultati di due approcci differenti all'apprendimento attivo: il cumulative e l'iterative. Il titolo del grafico √® "Active Learning: Cumulative vs Iterative Update". I grafici sono categorizzati in quattro modelli: Random, Entropy, CoreSet, CAL e PRC. Ogni modello ha una barra blu che rappresenta i risultati del cumulative e una barra gialla che rappresenta i risultati iterativi.
